summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida to defense attorney Jack Goldberger, formally notifying him of the individuals the U.S. government was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment against Jeffrey Epstein. The letter is issued as part of the conditions of Epstein's non-prosecution agreement, which deferred federal prosecution in favor of his state plea and sentence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the letter; he pleaded guilty to state charges of solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution and was sentenced to imprisonment, leading to a deferred federal prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jack A. Goldberger
persons.context: The recipient of the letter, an attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein, being formally notified of the list of individuals the U.S. was prepared to name as victims.

connections.description: Goldberger is identified as Epstein's attorney, receiving official legal correspondence on his behalf regarding the non-prosecution agreement and victim list.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty in Palm Beach County Circuit Court to felony solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution. He was sentenced to 12 months' imprisonment, followed by 6 months' imprisonment, then 12 months of community control.

events.title: Notification of Prepared Victim List
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sends this letter to Epstein's attorney, Jack Goldberger, formally providing the list of individuals the United States was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment, as required by the non-prosecution agreement.

locations: 15th Judicial Circuit in and for Palm Beach County
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to state charges (solicitation and procurement of minors for prostitution) on June 30, 2008, receiving an 18-month jail sentence followed by 12 months of community control.
The U.S. government agreed to defer federal prosecution in favor of the state plea and sentence, subject to conditions outlined in a non-prosecution agreement.
A key condition of the agreement was that victims would retain rights under federal law (18 U.S.C. ยง 2255) as if Epstein had been federally convicted.
This letter serves as the formal notice to Epstein's attorney, Jack Goldberger, identifying the individuals the U.S. was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment.
The document explicitly states the intent is to place the identified victims in the same legal position they would have been in had Epstein been convicted at a federal trial.
